description.narrative: Somalia remains one of the world#s longest running conflicts. According to UNHCR, around 1.1 Million Somalis are refugees and manymore are IDP#s within their country. They face increased vulnerability due to conflicts, recurrent droughts, poor governance and security challenges. Women and children are the most affected and have seen increased occurrences of injustices, violence, harassmentsand abuses and killing. Families have been forced to migrate from their homes and into poverty resulting in malnutrition and high rates of maternal mortality among others. The effects of war and conflicts continue for years after the fighting ends. Many women areleft widowed and children are orphaned. Women struggle to sustain livelihoods for their children after conflict. Through these challenges faced by Somali women, they play a very crucial role in peace building and conflict resolution. Women#s multiple clan affiliations give them a structural role as a peace builder, enabling them to become a channel for dialogue between warring parties and to exert pressure on them to keep talking and brining about solutions. Somali women play a role in influencing elders and others to intervene in conflict and mobilizing resources to finance peace meetings and support demobilization. There is limited information recorded on Somali women contributions towards peace-building and conflict resolution especially in areas like Somaliland where they havesucceeded in bringing about lasting peace in their communities. This research will fill the gap and examine the role of women in conflicts resolution and peace building. It will document previous efforts, lessons learnt and find out what has been done. Within thecontext of UN Security Council Resolution 1325, a comprehensive analysis of the situation will be done identifying gaps, clearing assumptions and exploring new ways of promoting women in the peace-building missions.

participating-org.narrative: Nagaad is the women#s network in Somaliland, which ON has been supporting since its establishment in1997. Nagaad was formed by 32 women#s groups in Hargeisa. While it has raised its profile tremendously after 2000, with a range of advocacy and publicity actions in the media, notably around women#s political participation, it has always remained a of 32 member organisations, many of them remain weak, except for a few larger ones (some of whom are also counterparts of Oxfam Novib). Nagaad built its own office and received support from a variety of donors. Over the last four years Nagaad has elaborated a restructuring plan and a new strategic plan that involves: (a) more focus on networking instead of direct implementation; (b) admission of 15 new members from the regions of Somaliland, and working relationships with regional women#s umbrellas and professional associations. The network now has a membership of 46organisations.
